title: 103_hr2357
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Women's Business Procurement Assistance Act of 1993". The goal setting section is also included. SEC. 2. GOAL SETTING. Section 15(g) of the Small Business Act is amended to include small business concerns owned and controlled by women in various paragraphs. SEC. 3. REPORTING. Section 15(h) of the Small Business Act is amended to include small business concerns owned and controlled by women in contracts and subcontracts. The Administration is required to submit information obtained from reports to the Senate and House Small Business Committees. Section 15(h) of the Small Business Act is amended to include small business concerns owned and controlled by women in contracts and subcontracts. SEC. 4. SUBCONTRACTING. The Small Business Act is amended to include small business concerns owned and controlled by women in its policies and contract clauses. The Small Business Act is amended to define 'small business concern' and 'small business concern owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals' in contract clauses. The Small Business Act defines 'small business concern owned and controlled by women' as a business that is at least 51% owned by women. The contractor should presume that socially and economically disadvantaged individuals include Black Americans, Hispanic Americans, Native Americans, Asian Pacific Americans, and other minorities. The Small Business Act defines 'small business concern owned and controlled by women' as a business that is at least 51% owned by women. Contractors should presume gender-based discrimination and may determine eligibility without regard to community property laws. Amendments include adding 'small business concerns owned and controlled by women' in various sections. No business concern shall be eligible for contracts under section 2323 of title 10. No business concern shall be eligible for contracts under section 2323 of title 10, United States Code, due solely to the provisions of this section. SEC. 5. WOMEN-IN-BUSINESS SPECIALISTS. Section 15(k) of the Small Business Act is amended to designate an employee as a women-in-business specialist. The Small Business Act is amended to designate a women-in-business specialist in federal agencies, ensuring they have the necessary knowledge and training to assist small business concerns owned by women. The Small Business Act is amended to designate a women-in-business specialist in federal agencies to assist small business concerns owned and controlled by women in participating in agency contracts. The specialist's responsibilities include responding to requests, soliciting offers, and monitoring progress towards meeting annual participation goals. SEC. 6. OUTREACH.

Federal agencies with procurement powers must actively seek offers from small businesses owned by women and socially disadvantaged individuals. These businesses should receive solicitation packages for eligible acquisitions.

SEC. 7. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE OFFICE OF WOMEN'S BUSINESS OWNERSHIP.

A new section is added to the Small Business Act to establish the Office of Women's Business Ownership. The Office of Women's Business Ownership is established within the Small Business Administration, with a Director appointed to promote and coordinate programs for small businesses owned by women. The Office of Women's Business Ownership, under the Small Business Administration, works to promote and support small businesses owned by women through policies, guidelines, and coordination with various groups and government entities. The Office of Women's Business Ownership, under the Small Business Administration, assesses progress in assisting small businesses owned by women and consults with various groups to develop new ideas. They also consider research findings on women entrepreneurs' challenges and monitor contracting activities. The Office of Women's Business Ownership, under the Small Business Administration, monitors contracting and subcontracting performance, promotes access for women-owned small businesses, and provides training to women-in-business specialists. SEC. 8. GENERAL ACCOUNTING OFFICE REPORT. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress comparing the number of small businesses owned by women before and after the enactment of this Act. If there is no significant increase in the number of such businesses after 3 years, recommendations for increasing them must be included in the report. If the report shows no significant increase, it is the sense of Congress to take action to address this issue. Congress should take further legislative steps to ensure that the number of Federal contracts with small businesses owned by women reflects their potential for Federal contracting work.
